description: Susan Watts/New York Daily News The Metropolitan Museum of Art can now charge an entrance fee of $25 or more. The Met has acquired a new masterpiece - a lease that allows it to charge museumgoers whatever it wants. And the museum has a well-known and wealthy arts patron to thank: Mayor Bloomberg.

related.description: MUSEUMS USED TO stand for something old, dusty, boring and barely relevant to real life. Those kinds of places still exist, but there are far fewer of them, and the more successful ones have changed out of all recognition.
related.title: Temples of delight

related.description: The Bronx Museum of the Arts organized a V.I.P. luncheon in October that featured the actor Chazz Palminteri telling stories from his one-man show "A Bronx Tale," eggplant Parmesan sandwiches made on Arthur Avenue, and even free shuttle service to and from Midtown Manhattan.
related.title: Bronx Arts Museum Reaches Out to Borough Alumni

related.description: New Year's Eve is a time for extravagant dresses, decorative headdresses and oversize necklaces. Shown here: designs worn at some of the best parties over the last 12 months - a preview of sorts for the Metropolitan Museum of Art exhibition of Charles James's spectacular ball gowns, opening in May.
related.title: Bill Cunningham | Start the Countdown

related.description: A mailbox. A Euro coin. A vacuum cleaner. The latest exhibit at Design Museum London, Extraordinary Stories About Ordinary Things , is full of objects that are utterly familiar to most of us. But does their ubiquity negate their quality as pieces of design? Not according to museum director Deyan Sudjic.
related.title: 13 Brilliant But Quotidian Design Classics

title: Mayor Bloomberg grants Metropolitan Museum of Art right to charge mandatory entrance fee
content:
Susan Watts/New York Daily News

The Metropolitan Museum of Art can now charge an entrance fee of $25 or more.

The Met has acquired a new masterpiece - a lease that allows it to charge museumgoers whatever it wants.

And the museum has a well-known and wealthy arts patron to thank: Mayor Bloomberg.

Hizzoner waded into the legal dispute over the Metropolitan Museum of Art's admissions practices by granting it the right to impose a mandatory entrance fee of $25 or more.

RELATED: METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART OFFERS GROUPON DEAL FOR ADMISSION AS LAWSUITS ARGUE CUSTOMERS SHOULD BE ALLOWED IN FOR FREE

The museum had come under fire for posting signs that critics say are designed to confuse people into thinking the fee is mandatory.

Bloomberg's decision was disclosed Thursday when the museum notified a Manhattan judge it has signed a new lease "at the city's request."

Leases for the American Museum of Natural History and the Museum of the City of New York were similarly amended, officials said.

RELATED: NY MET MUSEUM DROPS ADMISSION BUTTONS, STARTS 7-DAY WEEK

Lawyer Michael Hiller, who has filed one of two lawsuits against the Met claiming it duped museumgoers, blasted the new lease.

"The museum's effort to arrange a lease amendment, in the dead of night, without notice to the public and without regard to the democratic process, is nothing but a desperate stunt by the museum to defeat claims its lawyers must know are valid," Hiller said.

"It won't sell politically. It won't pass muster legally, and if anything, merely reinforces the fact the museum has been violating the lease for the last 43 years and that it must stop."

The mayor's office declined comment.

The amended lease - signed by Parks Commissioner Veronica White - says the museum can "set the terms of admission to its permanent galleries to the general public" with the consent of the commissioner of the City of New Department of Cultural Affairs.

entities.name: City of New Department of Cultural Affairs
